awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Ultrasensitive Solution-Processed Inverted Infrared Polymer Photodetectors
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to design, fabricate and optimize ultrasensitive solution-processed polymer photodetectors with spectral responses ranging from 350 to 2600 nm that operate at room temperature. The objective will be accomplished by tuning the electronic functionality of the materials and optimizing the inverted device performance.

The intellectual merit includes the development of ultrasensitive inverted infrared polymer photodetectors that possess significant advantages over state-of-the-art inorganic photodetectors.  These advantages include solution processing methods for device fabrication and energy savings from ambient temperature operation. Polymer photodetectors that do not require cooling to obtain high detectivity would be a transformative breakthrough. Moreover, low-cost multi-color, high sensitivity and high-speed response over a broad spectral range would have a number of applications across multiple technology platforms. This program will advance the fundamental understanding about the chemical and morphological properties of the electronic materials and the inverted device architecture in the enhancement of device performance. 

The broader impacts of this program are found in the development of ultrasensitive inverted infrared photodetectors, which offer resolutions and sensitivities currently unachievable. The development of this technology at The University of Akron will increase the participation of the students in science, technology, engineering and mathematics disciplines by engaging K-12, high school and undergraduate students using inquiry-based methods. Hands on learning activities including Science Olympiad rocket design and "plastic" electronics modules mimic the proposed research outcomes. The highly interdisciplinary research provides a stimulating environment ideally suited for the education and training of graduate students, undergraduate students and high-school students.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this award was to design, fabricate and optimize uncooled ultrasensitive solution-processed polymer photodetectors with spectral responses ranging from 350 to 2600 nm. The project spanned a wide range, including development of novel materials, new phenomena and related device performance of photodetectors.

 The intellectual merit includes the development of uncooled ultrasensitive solution-processed broadband photodetectors that possess significant advantages over state-of-the-art inorganic photodetectors. These advantages include solution processing methods for device fabrication and energy savings from ambient temperature operation. Solution-processed broadband photodetectors that do not require cooling to obtain high detectivity would be a transformative breakthrough. Moreover, low-cost multi-color, high sensitivity and high-speed response over a broad spectral range would have a number of applications across multiple technology platforms. This program will advance the fundamental understanding about the chemical and morphological properties of the electronic materials and the inverted device architecture in the enhancement of device performance.

 The broader impacts of this program are found in the development of ultrasensitive broadband photodetectors, which offer resolutions and sensitivities currently unachievable. The development of this technology at The University of Akron will increase the participation of the students in science, technology, engineering and mathematics disciplines by engaging K-12, high school and undergraduate students using inquiry-based methods. Hands on learning activities including Science Olympiad rocket design and "plastic" electronics modules mimic the proposed research outcomes. The highly interdisciplinary research provides a stimulating environment ideally suited for the education and training of graduate students, undergraduate students and high-school students

 In the past 5 years, we demonstrated uncooled solution-processed polymer photodetectors by novel low-bandgap conjugated polymers with spectral response from 300 nm to 2500 nm; We also demonstrated uncooled solution-processed photodetectors by novel perovskites incorporated with carbon nanotubes and novel n-type low-bandgap conjugated polymers; we also developed uncooled ultrasensitive broadband photodetectors by double-layer structure composing of solution-processed PbSe coated with different organic ligands through photomultiplication effect and by double-layer structure composing of solution-processed highly electrical conductive PbSe QDs on the top of solution-processed perovskite thin film to boost spectral response from visible to infrared regions and enhance the detectivity through photomultiplication effect; Uncooled solution-processed flexible photodetectors with spectral response from 300 nm to 2600 nm was demonstrated. 6 Ph. D. students and 20 master students, 4 REU students, 1 RET teacher, 4 undergraduates were participated in this project.  About 40 publications supported by this project were produced.
